text: [music playing]

Welcome to AWS conversations
with leaders.
My name is Miriam McLemore,

and I'm an Enterprise
Strategist with AWS.

And I am absolutely thrilled today
to have as our guest, Joy Lewin.

She is the Senior Director
of Commercial Development
at Ferring Pharmaceuticals.

Joy, thank you so much
for spending some time with us today.
Very glad to be here with you.

Well, Joy, you know, I've had
the great opportunity

to read about your career
and all of your accomplishments.

Could you tell us
a little bit more about
Ferring and your role at Ferring?

We're a biopharmaceutical
research-driven organization.

We develop and market products
for reproductive medicine,

maternal health, gastroenterology
and orthopedics.

In fact, Ferring is one of the world
leaders in reproductive medicine.
At Ferring people come first.

I am Senior Director of Commercial
Development and Key Accounts.
I am committed to developing programs

to allow patients easier access
into fertility treatments.

So can you tell us a little bit
about that marketplace,

the reproductive health
and fertility marketplace?
This is a very exciting marketplace.

IVF is relatively young,
it's only 42 years old.
And I've been here most of that time.
And I've been able in my career

be able to meet
the first IVF baby in the world,

who is Louise Brown,
and she's 42 years old.
She was conceived and born in the UK.

I was also fortunate to be able to
meet the first IVF baby in the U.S.,

who was conceived at the Jones
Institute in Norfolk, Virginia.

I can't even begin to tell you
how wonderful it's been to be able

to learn and share along the way
and experience

the advances that had been made
in reproductive medicine.

I love that. And you were
actually honored in 2017
for a program that you created,

I believe it's called
the HeartBeat Program.

Could you share a little bit
more about that?

Yes, now in 2012, we came up
with a program
and Ferring was very much behind it

to provide hope and a family to these
newly diagnosed cancer patients.

So the program involves patients
getting access

to Ferring
fertility medications at no cost.
We started this program in 2012,

and it's still going
strong today in 2021.

It's an amazing program,
and we're so proud to be behind this.

And I'm sure maybe some
of our listeners

are thinking really no cost,
is that true?
That is true.

We are really committed
to helping patients.

As I said, the mission of Ferring
is people come first.

So we really believe that being able
to provide hope

to these newly
diagnosed cancer patients,

that they can have a family
after they finish their treatments.

Wow, what a weight lifted from these
patients when you're newly diagnosed,

and helping them know that, you know,
hey, we got to think about fertility.

I know you're thinking about
this diagnosis,

but we're going to help you
just, you know,

make sure that your future
is as you might want it to be.

So what a great gift to people
going through such a terrible time?

Through this, obviously,
you've driven a lot of innovation.

Can you tell us what do you think
innovation means?

Innovation is just a different way
of thinking
about things with a positive outcome.

As you can see, I'm very passionate
about this market space.

I'm always trying to think
of new ways to do things

from a marketing perspective,
or a commercial perspective

that would help patients take
their first step in their journey,

because that seems to be
their biggest obstacle.

And so we encourage this innovative
thinking by the project

that we started with AWS
and the Digital Innovation Group,

where we actually sat down,
took the problem, dissected it,

and came up with a really,
really cool solution.

Joy, in all of this work that you've
done and in the partnership with AWS,

you have looked at the customer base
that you are targeting,

couples that are suffering
from infertility.

Can you walk us through the numbers
and the outreach
that you're trying to get,

the target audience
you're trying to speak to?

In the U.S., there are 6.5 million
people

that could probably benefit
by some fertility treatments.

So the way the numbers look is,
so in this market space,

there's 6.5 million because
it's one in every eight couples.
So what happens from there?

So at any given time, there's 2.2
million who are trying to conceive.

Of that 2.2 million, 800,000 of them
will be going to their OB-GYN
or their family practitioner,

and able to conceive,
so that leaves 1.4 million people.

So what happens after that?
In the U.S.

today,
only approximately 300,000 people

ever make an appointment
to visit a fertility specialist,

and of that,
the numbers keep going down,

and maybe half of those
actually go through treatment.

So you see that the market is that
there are patients

that really need treatment
that are not accessing the treatment.

So Ferring and our marketing team
are committed to really trying

to find a way to get these couples
the treatment that they need

so that they can have
the family of their dreams.

What have you found
to be the biggest barrier

to that difference
in numbers of customers,

people that could benefit
from treatment

and those that actually
seek treatment?
Is it fear of expense?
What’s the barrier that you found?

Okay, so everybody always just
reverts to cost,
is the number one barrier.

And in the last couple of years,
we made a concerted effort

to really try to understand what is
really behind all of these barriers,

why more people are not
accessing treatment?

We did market research with about
2,000 potential patients

and really what we found above
and beyond cost,

was really their own basic fears
and emotions

that are precluding them
from taking their first step.

So we took that data that we knew
from the market research,

brought it with us to our AWS
Digital Innovation workshop,

and started to begin to problem
solve,

how can we help these people
take their first step?

So Joy, you mentioned this Digital
Innovation workshop that AWS leads,

and I've had great opportunity to do
the part of those kinds of workshops,

and that really starts with
a customer problem statement.

And then we work backwards
from that to truly understand,
as you rightly described,

what is the real problem
that needs to be addressed

to enable us
to do the customer value,

so we reach more people
with treatment
that can add value to their lives?

What was your learning
coming through that workshop?

I loved the process
because it was so different.

And it really made us sit down
and think what are we doing here,
and what are we try to accomplish?

And I think the lightning rod
experience, my aha moment was,
let's stop focusing on cost

and let's really speak to the
emotional burden that these women,

couples have that preclude them
from taking their first step.

And so that's how we began to process
this
with this multidisciplinary group

of all these different people
around the table

and going through
the working backwards process,

which really was eye opening for
most of us sitting around the table.

I love that.
So let's jump into the program.

Can you tell us a little bit about
the first step

that you guys took
once you got these insights?

You developed the program and then
you kind of started the piloting.
Tell us about that?

Well, I think the first step was,
as I said, we focused
and recognized the emotional burden.

So then it was like, what can we do
to help patients
take that first step?

So the first iteration
of Fertility House

Calls 1.0 was that we would…
working together with

AWS, Slalom as our partner
to build the digital platform,

and a local clinic in Denver,
Colorado.

And the program then we decided
should be Fertility House Calls

where the clinic
would send out a nurse

and a financial counselor
to sit down with the couple

and discuss
very personalized approach,

what their
treatment options could be.

The goal was to make it
a much easier process.

So we rolled this out
in January of 2020,

and then all of a sudden,
March COVID hit, put on the brakes.
So then what did we do?

We went back to the drawing board
and we were able to leverage

what we'd already
invested in building the platform,
we were able to take advantage

of the acceptance
of these virtual telehealth consults.

So we were able to leverage
everything that we did

in terms of the investment
we made with the platform.

And then all of a sudden, we said,
okay, we're going to do

a robust media plan, social media,
paid media, earned media,
drive patients to a website.

At that website with one click
of a button,

they can instantly then schedule
a virtual telehealth visit
with a clinic near to their home.

At that moment, then an email
goes back to the patient
confirming the request

and at the same moment
through the AWS cloud,
the scheduler sitting in the clinic,

can then reach out to the patient
and create the appointment.
Joy, I love that, one,

just coming up with a concept
of house calls in today's world,

but then also
being able to so quickly pivot
that given the complexities of COVID,

and actually probably reach
a much broader audience

than you may have been previously
able to with the, you know,

what we traditionally think of
a house call having to go to someone.

Is that what you’ve seen because
your original target
was reach more people?

Has this crisis actually created
some value for you in that way?

So basically, we rolled out
the program November 9.
We started in eight key markets,

and now we're currently
in 12 markets.

And we have over 100 clinic
networks and clinic groups

on the site with over
275 individual locations.
I mean, it's amazing.

And in February, we hit 1,000
patient appointment requests.

I mean, we were so excited with
the success that we're having.

I mean, now we're in 12 markets,
and we plan to roll the program

out throughout the United States
by the end of September.

So it looks like it's working
and we're really excited.

But we're not done.
I mean, we've just begun.

We need to think
10 chess moves ahead.

I'm already talking to your
digital innovation group
and Slalom about what can we do next.

Because what we know about
the marketplace is this,
is that 50% of the people

that go to that initial consult,
never come back.

And that's why the numbers are,
you know, continue to get lower

and lower than actually receive
treatment within a year.

So we're not done,
we're just getting started.

And I look forward
to talking to you again
in the very near future

with more iterations of our
Fertility House Calls project.
Wow, amazing journey.

Joy, thank you so much
for spending time with us

and sharing such a fantastic program
that you've innovated.
And we'll continue to iterate

and we are thrilled
to be partners with you

and with Slalom
as you drive this change

for very important need
in the market. Thank you.

And thank you.
I'm so grateful for this opportunity
to be able to share this with others.

And you know, in my head,
it's you think about technology

and you think about
these digital solutions.

But I think the thing that AWS
continued to drive us
and bring us back, realize back in,

you know, keeping the customer
in the center of everything,

the patient is at the heart
of everything we do.

And then the digital solution
or the technology piece comes after.

So we were able to then in that
process,
put that patient at the center,

and then it evolved into creating
this engagement platform
and the services that we can provide.
Like I said, we've only just begun.

- Thank you.
- Well, cheers to you. Thank you.
[music playing]
